column2: Postal, Hatred, and Weighing the Worth of Asshole Simulators
column7:
This video is an in-depth critical deconstruction of the Postal franchise from Running With Scissors as well as Hatred from Destructive Creations. It looks at the deliberate jackassery that defines the player experience in these games and considers the merit of the games from a mechanical, cultural, and personal level.

Content warning for gamified sexual assault, a lot of cock and balls stuff, and a whole heap of racism and sexism.

"When I wrote "truly great games, that are obviously made with a lot of heart and passion, go unnoticed and left behind in favour of shoddy games that don't seem nearly as deserving of the attention", I was not at all referring to the Postal series. It would be non-sensical if I did, because among its target audience, I believe Postal has done quite well for itself. You are right that Postal has niche appeal, and for a niche product I think it has been quite successful. Besides, as I am not an employee of RWS, and receive no monetary reward for that article, or for sales of any Postal title, I had no reason to express resent over the success or failure of Postal as a product. I wrote the article to express exactly what is written - support of gamers, and game makers, who have either gone unnoticed or antagonized by the gaming press. I know I am treading on ground where you might disagree with that, but it is sincerely where I was coming from.

There are many other inaccuracies among the claims you make, that I would have liked to tackle, but I'm not a member of RWS and I am confident that they can stand up for themselves. So I'm only here to address the instance where you used my words specifically, to paint an inaccurate picture of RWS, as being sore that (using your stated interpretation of my article) Postal isn't as successful as Depression Quest (which is obviously a ridiculous assertion, but that's what I got from your statements. Please let me know if I misinterpreted). This should be an easy fix, with a simple annotation during that segment of your video, explaining that my article isn't actually saying what you're claiming that it is. column2: Arcanum & Vampire: Bloodlines-- Lost Classics of Troika Games
column7:
This is a video retrospective of legendary, long-defunct Troika Games' two most memorable titles-- Arcanum: of Steamworks and Magic Obscura, Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines. It looks at both games in depth, considering them for their own merits and their legacy in gaming history. If you've heard about these classic games but haven't seen them in action, or if you're looking for an in-depth critical retrospective, why not spend forty minutes with these Lost Classics of Troika Games? column2: Creative Accounting: The Sub-Subgenre of Survival Strategy
column7:
This is a video critique and survey of four games in the niche subgenre of survival strategy. It begins with Outpost 1 (1994) and Outpost 2 (1997) from Sierra On-Line, before moving into the modern age with Haemimont Game's Surviving Mars and Frostpunk from 11-Bit Studios. It looks at how the games share a unique tone and rhythm, and how the emphasis on those elements sets the games apart from other strategy subgenres.

column2: Monster Mash-- Horizon: Zero Dawn vs. Days Gone
column7:
This is a comparative video critique of Guerilla Game's Horizon Zero Dawn and its Frozen Wilds expansion with Sony of Bend's Days Gone. They're both PS4 exclusive open world titles that are, on a surface level, extremely similar but on closer examination show themselves to be diagonally opposite games.
